f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:13): in microdata, can someone clarify for me how I'm supposed to use the "fn" and "n" properties in the vcard vocabulary?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:14): I don't get why both "fn" and "n" exist, or why "fn" must be present if "n" is present
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:16): I think it's legacy constraints from the original vcard format.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:16): The microformats wiki page should explain their use pretty well.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:16): It was sensical enough for me to use it on my pages, at least.

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:19): But if I use <span itemprop="fn n">, then "n" actually needs to be an item, so that would become <span itemscope itemprop="fn n">, but "fn" is supposed to be a string, not an item, so then I would have to split them into two separate elements.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:19): or otherwise rely on the implied "n" optimisation
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:21): Hrm.  Yeah, I think you can't use them together in Microdata, and have to either put both of them in or use the implied "n" optimizations.

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:22): i'm baffled by the number of people who don't want the spec to encourage user agents to try to make things better for AT users in the face of authoring mistakes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:22): why do people want to pubish users for authoring mistakes?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:23): it's like the whole draconican parsing thing all over again
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:24): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I think people are either misreading the spec, or buying into a subtle argument about giving authors incorrect expectations
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:24): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, I think they're mostly asking to rephrase to be vaguer at this point, aren't they?

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:24): I don't think people are opposed to ATs providing a better user experience. They seem to be opposed to the spec setting seemingly unrealistic requirements and somehow giving authors unrealistic expectaions and choosing not to give alternative text

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:26): and since the purpose of the statement in the spec is to give implementations permission to use alternative techniques, it seems reasonable to say so without indicating what those techniques may be, especially when it could be misconstrued as referring to futuristic technologies

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:26): That is, I certainly don't want to punish users because authors were bad.  It totally makes sense that image-reading heuristics, when they exist and are practical, should be used in the absence of @alt.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:27): OCR is not a futuristic technology
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:27): I think it would probably fine to say that if alt is missing, UAs can present any other information they are able to get in lieu of a text alternative
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:27): I don't think it's clear to everyone that "image analysis heuristics" refers to things like OCR.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:27): and if specific examples are listed at all, they should be clearly realistic examples like using the filename or performing OCR
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:28): people seem to be thinking it refers to some kind of futuristic AI, that can look at a picture and determine what it is and what it means in context
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:28): there is shipping technology today that does painting recognition, OCR, landmark recognition, etc, on arbitrary images
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:28): which would really help users who can't see images
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:28): "User agents may also apply image analysis heuristics‚Ä¶" does seem to imply that such heuristics exist, when outside of OCR they don't reliably.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:29): yes, but those things, like Google Goggles, require large collections of sample images with which to compare the subject image with
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:29): there are in fact heuristics that can recognize all kinds of images other than images of text
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:29): Outside of images of text, though, you run into the intent problem.  A description of the image may not be valid alt text.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:29): sure
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:29): mostly either research projects, or somewhat experimental, and often requiring a huge corpus
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:29): but it's better than nothing!

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:30): it's not even that clear to me how I'd use the shipping Google Goggles to build an accessibility feature for a UA - uploading every image that lacks alt text seems like a bad idea for both bandwidth and privacy reasons

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:31): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, I just think you should try to find a way that makes the intent of the statement clear, without making people think the spec is setting unrealistic expectations
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:31): that being said, it seems like a much more general statement would both be less objectionable, and more broadly applicable
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:31): well i'd be happy to make the text even vaguer so long as we still explicitly allow such behaviour
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:32): (no bug was ever filed for this as far as i know, btw)

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:33): personally, I thought image analysis heuristics was a rather general statement already, and I don't agree with most of the rationale that was given in the change proposal
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:33): yeah i'm not exactly sure how to make it vaguer
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:33): maybe use less jargon

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:36): Change it to "User agents may also utilise any other available techniques or technologies to help the user make sense of the image when the user is unable to make direct use of the image, ..."
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:37): well it's not _any_ other
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:37): e.g. iirc we explicitly discourage use of the filename
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:37): since that has been shown to hurt more than help
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:38): that's an implementation decision though. There's no reason to have the spec explicitly disallow it
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:39): I think it might also help to say "get information about the image" instead of "make sense of the image"
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:39): since the latter seems to be what makes people think the technology described is science-fictional

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:39): also, the file name is not always useless. It is when it's a bunch of random letters or numbers, but if the AT recognises the file name as being readable words (e.g. by checking a dictionary), then why not use the file name as a last resort?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:40): yeah, many filenames are bad, but not all - the best thing would be for AT to use heuristics to determine if the file name is human-understandable
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:40): i could live with that

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:42): Here the suggested text again with some changes: "User agents may also utilise any other available techniques or technologies to help the user obtain information about the image when the user is unable to make direct use of the image, ..."

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:43): we should just come out and say what we mean
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:43): if you can find text that people find satisfactory then I'd be happy to try to put this one through as an amicable resolution

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:20): that's one of the biggest problems with RDFa, imho
